abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory,
            having contributed to positive developments in the financial
            sector, through the creation of the legal, and regulatory
            framework, conducive to a strong, and stable banking system.
            However, the timing for the reform process - the supervising
            agency was being strengthened at the breakout of the
            financial crisis - hindered the capacity, and experience in
            banking supervision, thus its sustainability remain
            uncertain. Lessons reinforce the notion that government
            commitment to, and ownership of a reform program, as in this
            case, is conducive to successful results. But as experience
            suggests, the implementation of a comprehensive reform
            approach, requires a consistent, and correct sequence of
            enterprise, and financial sector reform, to avoid, as
            mentioned above, an erroneous timing which may hamper
            financial sustainability. Nonetheless, the macroeconomic
            stability of the Kyrgyz Republic, paved the way to reduced
            volatility of capital flows, and enhanced the potential for
            safe financial management, which was instrumental in
            attracting investments, and facilitated credit risk
            management. To finalize, strong financial systems require
            enforcement powers, thus effective banking regulation, and
            preventive early-warning systems, and instruments for
            depositors protection, should be in place for effective
            on-site examination, and off-site surveillance.
